options.title: -L
options.description: Show license.

options.title: -h, -?, -help, --help [arg]
options.description:
Show help. An optional parameter may be specified to print help about a specific item. If no argument is specified, only basic (non advanced) tool options are shown.

Possible values of arg are:

long

Print advanced tool options in addition to the basic tool options.

full

Print complete list of options, including shared and private options for encoders, decoders, demuxers, muxers, filters, etc.

decoder=decoder_name

Print detailed information about the decoder named decoder_name. Use the -decoders option to get a list of all decoders.

encoder=encoder_name

Print detailed information about the encoder named encoder_name. Use the -encoders option to get a list of all encoders.

demuxer=demuxer_name

Print detailed information about the demuxer named demuxer_name. Use the -formats option to get a list of all demuxers and muxers.

muxer=muxer_name

Print detailed information about the muxer named muxer_name. Use the -formats option to get a list of all muxers and demuxers.

filter=filter_name

Print detailed information about the filter named filter_name. Use the -filters option to get a list of all filters.

bsf=bitstream_filter_name

Print detailed information about the bitstream filter named bitstream_filter_name. Use the -bsfs option to get a list of all bitstream filters.

protocol=protocol_name

Print detailed information about the protocol named protocol_name. Use the -protocols option to get a list of all protocols.

options.title: -h, -?, -help, --help [arg]
options.description:
Show help. An optional parameter may be specified to print help about a specific item. If no argument is specified, only basic (non advanced) tool options are shown.

Possible values of arg are:

long

Print advanced tool options in addition to the basic tool options.

full

Print complete list of options, including shared and private options for encoders, decoders, demuxers, muxers, filters, etc.

decoder=decoder_name

Print detailed information about the decoder named decoder_name. Use the -decoders option to get a list of all decoders.

encoder=encoder_name

Print detailed information about the encoder named encoder_name. Use the -encoders option to get a list of all encoders.

demuxer=demuxer_name

Print detailed information about the demuxer named demuxer_name. Use the -formats option to get a list of all demuxers and muxers.

muxer=muxer_name

Print detailed information about the muxer named muxer_name. Use the -formats option to get a list of all muxers and demuxers.

filter=filter_name

Print detailed information about the filter named filter_name. Use the -filters option to get a list of all filters.

bsf=bitstream_filter_name

Print detailed information about the bitstream filter named bitstream_filter_name. Use the -bsfs option to get a list of all bitstream filters.

protocol=protocol_name

Print detailed information about the protocol named protocol_name. Use the -protocols option to get a list of all protocols.

options.title: -version
options.description: Show version.

options.title: -buildconf
options.description: Show the build configuration, one option per line.

options.title: -formats
options.description: Show available formats (including devices).

options.title: -demuxers
options.description: Show available demuxers.

options.title: -muxers
options.description: Show available muxers.

options.title: -devices
options.description: Show available devices.

options.title: -codecs
options.description:
Show all codecs known to libavcodec.

Note that the term ’codec’ is used throughout this documentation as a shortcut for what is more correctly called a media bitstream format.

options.title: -decoders
options.description: Show available decoders.

options.title: -encoders
options.description: Show all available encoders.

options.title: -bsfs
options.description: Show available bitstream filters.

options.title: -protocols
options.description: Show available protocols.

options.title: -filters
options.description: Show available libavfilter filters.

options.title: -pix_fmts
options.description: Show available pixel formats.

options.title: -sample_fmts
options.description: Show available sample formats.

options.title: -layouts
options.description: Show channel names and standard channel layouts.

options.title: -colors
options.description: Show recognized color names.

options.title: -sources device[, opt1=val1[, opt2=val2]...]
options.description:
Show autodetected sources of the input device. Some devices may provide system-dependent source names that cannot be autodetected. The returned list cannot be assumed to be always complete.

ffmpeg -sources pulse,server=192.168.0.4

options.title: -sinks device[, opt1=val1[, opt2=val2]...]
options.description:
Show autodetected sinks of the output device. Some devices may provide system-dependent sink names that cannot be autodetected. The returned list cannot be assumed to be always complete.

ffmpeg -sinks pulse,server=192.168.0.4

options.title: -loglevel [flags+]loglevel | -v [flags+]loglevel
options.description:
Set logging level and flags used by the library.

The optional flags prefix can consist of the following values:

‘repeat’

Indicates that repeated log output should not be compressed to the first line and the "Last message repeated n times" line will be omitted.

‘level’

Indicates that log output should add a [level] prefix to each message line. This can be used as an alternative to log coloring, e.g. when dumping the log to file.

Flags can also be used alone by adding a ’+’/’-’ prefix to set/reset a single flag without affecting other flags or changing loglevel. When setting both flags and loglevel, a ’+’ separator is expected between the last flags value and before loglevel.

loglevel is a string or a number containing one of the following values:

‘quiet, -8’

Show nothing at all; be silent.

‘panic, 0’

Only show fatal errors which could lead the process to crash, such as an assertion failure. This is not currently used for anything.

‘fatal, 8’

Only show fatal errors. These are errors after which the process absolutely cannot continue.

‘error, 16’

Show all errors, including ones which can be recovered from.

‘warning, 24’

Show all warnings and errors. Any message related to possibly incorrect or unexpected events will be shown.

‘info, 32’

Show informative messages during processing. This is in addition to warnings and errors. This is the default value.

‘verbose, 40’

Same as info, except more verbose.

‘debug, 48’

Show everything, including debugging information.

‘trace, 56’

For example to enable repeated log output, add the level prefix, and set loglevel to verbose:

ffmpeg -loglevel repeat+level+verbose -i input output

Another example that enables repeated log output without affecting current state of level prefix flag or loglevel:

ffmpeg [...] -loglevel +repeat

By default the program logs to stderr. If coloring is supported by the terminal, colors are used to mark errors and warnings. Log coloring can be disabled setting the environment variable AV_LOG_FORCE_NOCOLOR, or can be forced setting the environment variable AV_LOG_FORCE_COLOR.

options.title: -report
options.description:
Dump full command line and log output to a file named program-YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS.log in the current directory. This file can be useful for bug reports. It also implies -loglevel debug.

Setting the environment variable FFREPORT to any value has the same effect. If the value is a ’:’-separated key=value sequence, these options will affect the report; option values must be escaped if they contain special characters or the options delimiter ’:’ (see the “Quoting and escaping” section in the ffmpeg-utils manual).

The following options are recognized:

file

set the file name to use for the report; %p is expanded to the name of the program, %t is expanded to a timestamp, %% is expanded to a plain %

level

set the log verbosity level using a numerical value (see -loglevel).

For example, to output a report to a file named ffreport.log using a log level of 32 (alias for log level info):

FFREPORT=file=ffreport.log:level=32 ffmpeg -i input output

Errors in parsing the environment variable are not fatal, and will not appear in the report.

options.title: -hide_banner
options.description:
Suppress printing banner.

All FFmpeg tools will normally show a copyright notice, build options and library versions. This option can be used to suppress printing this information.

options.title: -cpuflags flags (global)
options.description:
Allows setting and clearing cpu flags. This option is intended for testing. Do not use it unless you know what you’re doing.

ffmpeg -cpuflags -sse+mmx ...
ffmpeg -cpuflags mmx ...
ffmpeg -cpuflags 0 ...

Possible flags for this option are:

‘x86’ ‘mmx’ ‘mmxext’ ‘sse’ ‘sse2’ ‘sse2slow’ ‘sse3’ ‘sse3slow’ ‘ssse3’ ‘atom’ ‘sse4.1’ ‘sse4.2’ ‘avx’ ‘avx2’ ‘xop’ ‘fma3’ ‘fma4’ ‘3dnow’ ‘3dnowext’ ‘bmi1’ ‘bmi2’ ‘cmov’ ‘ARM’ ‘armv5te’ ‘armv6’ ‘armv6t2’ ‘vfp’ ‘vfpv3’ ‘neon’ ‘setend’ ‘AArch64’ ‘armv8’ ‘vfp’ ‘neon’ ‘PowerPC’ ‘altivec’ ‘Specific Processors’ ‘pentium2’ ‘pentium3’ ‘pentium4’ ‘k6’ ‘k62’ ‘athlon’ ‘athlonxp’ ‘k8’

options.title: -cpucount count (global)
options.description:
Override detection of CPU count. This option is intended for testing. Do not use it unless you know what you’re doing.

ffmpeg -cpucount 2

options.title: -max_alloc bytes
options.description: Set the maximum size limit for allocating a block on the heap by ffmpeg’s family of malloc functions. Exercise extreme caution when using this option. Don’t use if you do not understand the full consequence of doing so. Default is INT_MAX.

options.title: -x width
options.description: Force displayed width.

options.title: -y height
options.description: Force displayed height.

options.title: -s size
options.description: Set frame size (WxH or abbreviation), needed for videos which do not contain a header with the frame size like raw YUV. This option has been deprecated in favor of private options, try -video_size.

options.title: -fs
options.description: Start in fullscreen mode.

options.title: -an
options.description: Disable audio.

options.title: -vn
options.description: Disable video.

options.title: -sn
options.description: Disable subtitles.

options.title: -ss pos
options.description:
Seek to pos. Note that in most formats it is not possible to seek exactly, so ffplay will seek to the nearest seek point to pos.

pos must be a time duration specification, see (ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual.

options.title: -t duration
options.description:
Play duration seconds of audio/video.

duration must be a time duration specification, see (ffmpeg-utils)the Time duration section in the ffmpeg-utils(1) manual.

options.title: -bytes
options.description: Seek by bytes.

options.title: -seek_interval
options.description: Set custom interval, in seconds, for seeking using left/right keys. Default is 10 seconds.

options.title: -nodisp
options.description: Disable graphical display.

options.title: -noborder
options.description: Borderless window.

options.title: -alwaysontop
options.description: Window always on top. Available on: X11 with SDL >= 2.0.5, Windows SDL >= 2.0.6.

options.title: -volume
options.description: Set the startup volume. 0 means silence, 100 means no volume reduction or amplification. Negative values are treated as 0, values above 100 are treated as 100.

options.title: -f fmt
options.description: Force format.

options.title: -window_title title
options.description: Set window title (default is the input filename).

options.title: -left title
options.description: Set the x position for the left of the window (default is a centered window).

options.title: -top title
options.description: Set the y position for the top of the window (default is a centered window).

options.title: -loop number
options.description: Loops movie playback <number> times. 0 means forever.

options.title: -showmode mode
options.description:
Set the show mode to use. Available values for mode are:

‘0, video’

show video

‘1, waves’

show audio waves

‘2, rdft’

show audio frequency band using RDFT ((Inverse) Real Discrete Fourier Transform)

Default value is "video", if video is not present or cannot be played "rdft" is automatically selected.

You can interactively cycle through the available show modes by pressing the key w.

options.title: -vf filtergraph
options.description:
Create the filtergraph specified by filtergraph and use it to filter the video stream.

filtergraph is a description of the filtergraph to apply to the stream, and must have a single video input and a single video output. In the filtergraph, the input is associated to the label in, and the output to the label out. See the ffmpeg-filters manual for more information about the filtergraph syntax.

You can specify this parameter multiple times and cycle through the specified filtergraphs along with the show modes by pressing the key w.

options.title: -af filtergraph
options.description: filtergraph is a description of the filtergraph to apply to the input audio. Use the option "-filters" to show all the available filters (including sources and sinks).

options.title: -i input_url
options.description: Read input_url.

options.title: -pix_fmt format
options.description: Set pixel format. This option has been deprecated in favor of private options, try -pixel_format.

options.title: -stats
options.description: Print several playback statistics, in particular show the stream duration, the codec parameters, the current position in the stream and the audio/video synchronisation drift. It is shown by default, unless the log level is lower than info. Its display can be forced by manually specifying this option. To disable it, you need to specify -nostats.

options.title: -fast
options.description: Non-spec-compliant optimizations.

options.title: -genpts
options.description: Generate pts.

options.title: -sync type
options.description: Set the master clock to audio (type=audio), video (type=video) or external (type=ext). Default is audio. The master clock is used to control audio-video synchronization. Most media players use audio as master clock, but in some cases (streaming or high quality broadcast) it is necessary to change that. This option is mainly used for debugging purposes.

options.title: -ast audio_stream_specifier
options.description: Select the desired audio stream using the given stream specifier. The stream specifiers are described in the Stream specifiers chapter. If this option is not specified, the "best" audio stream is selected in the program of the already selected video stream.

options.title: -vst video_stream_specifier
options.description: Select the desired video stream using the given stream specifier. The stream specifiers are described in the Stream specifiers chapter. If this option is not specified, the "best" video stream is selected.

options.title: -sst subtitle_stream_specifier
options.description: Select the desired subtitle stream using the given stream specifier. The stream specifiers are described in the Stream specifiers chapter. If this option is not specified, the "best" subtitle stream is selected in the program of the already selected video or audio stream.

options.title: -autoexit
options.description: Exit when video is done playing.

options.title: -exitonkeydown
options.description: Exit if any key is pressed.

options.title: -exitonmousedown
options.description: Exit if any mouse button is pressed.

options.title: -codec:media_specifier codec_name
options.description: Force a specific decoder implementation for the stream identified by media_specifier, which can assume the values a (audio), v (video), and s subtitle.

options.title: -acodec codec_name
options.description: Force a specific audio decoder.

options.title: -vcodec codec_name
options.description: Force a specific video decoder.

options.title: -scodec codec_name
options.description: Force a specific subtitle decoder.

options.title: -autorotate
options.description: Automatically rotate the video according to file metadata. Enabled by default, use -noautorotate to disable it.

options.title: -framedrop
options.description: Drop video frames if video is out of sync. Enabled by default if the master clock is not set to video. Use this option to enable frame dropping for all master clock sources, use -noframedrop to disable it.

options.title: -infbuf
options.description: Do not limit the input buffer size, read as much data as possible from the input as soon as possible. Enabled by default for realtime streams, where data may be dropped if not read in time. Use this option to enable infinite buffers for all inputs, use -noinfbuf to disable it.

options.title: -filter_threads nb_threads
options.description: Defines how many threads are used to process a filter pipeline. Each pipeline will produce a thread pool with this many threads available for parallel processing. The default is 0 which means that the thread count will be determined by the number of available CPUs.
